title: Quarto Test Slides
text: Second Slide

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Type Ia Supernovae
text:
#| label: load-packages #| include: false
import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression from sklearn.preprocessing import PolynomialFeatures from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error, mean_absolute_error, r2_score
sns.set_theme(style=“whitegrid”) sns.set_context(“notebook”, font_scale=1.1)
plt.rcParams[‘figure.dpi’] = 300 plt.rcParams[‘savefig.dpi’] = 300 plt.rcParams[‘figure.figsize’] = (6, 6 * 0.618)
#| label: load-data #| include: false
df = pd.read_csv(“../data/processed/clean_sn_data.csv”)
X = df[[‘d_L_Mpc’]].values y = df[‘velocity_kms’].values

Linear model (global)
lin_model = LinearRegression() lin_model.fit(X, y) y_pred = lin_model.predict(X)
rmse_lin = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y, y_pred)) mae_lin = mean_absolute_error(y, y_pred) r2_lin = r2_score(y, y_pred)


Quadratic model (curvature test)
poly = PolynomialFeatures(degree=2, include_bias=False) X_poly = poly.fit_transform(X)
poly_model = LinearRegression() poly_model.fit(X_poly, y) y_poly_pred = poly_model.predict(X_poly)
rmse_poly = np.sqrt(mean_squared_error(y, y_poly_pred)) mae_poly = mean_absolute_error(y, y_poly_pred)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Goal
-## Research Question

What functional form best describes the relationship between distance and recession velocity?
How does a simple linear model compare to more flexible models?
Estimate the Hubble constant (H₀) using Pantheon+ supernova data
Evaluate whether a simple linear Hubble Law fits well

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Data


Dataset: Pantheon+ supernovae (distance vs recessional velocity)
Pantheon+ provides high-quality Type Ia supernova distances
Focus on low-redshift regime where Hubble’s Law applies
Key variables: distance and velocity (after cleaning)

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Approach


Baseline model: linear regression (v = H₀ d)

Theory predicts proportional increase of velocity with distance
Slope provides an estimate of the Hubble constant

Check fit: residual patterns vs distance
Compare: linear vs quadratic (as a diagnostic, not expected physically at low z)


Linear Model


Theory predicts proportional increase of velocity with distance
Linear regression used to quantify this relationship
Slope provides an estimate of the Hubble constant


Linear Model Performance


RMSE ≈ 711 km/s
MAE low, indicating generally accurate predictions
High R² shows linear trend explains most variance


Model Performance


Linear model fit:

R² ≈ 0.98
RMSE ≈ 711 km/s

Estimated Hubble constant:

H₀ ≈ 65–67 km/s/Mpc

MAE low, indicating generally accurate predictions
High R² shows linear trend explains most variance


Hubble Diagram


Strong linear relationship between distance and velocity
Scatter increases at larger distances





Residual Analysis


Residuals mostly random at shorter distances
Slight trend appears only at largest distances
Suggests local deviations rather than global nonlinearity





Quadratic Model Test


Quadratic regression used to test for curvature
Expected improvement if curvature were meaningful
Model performed significantly worse


Model Comparison


Linear model RMSE ≈ 711 km/s
Quadratic model RMSE ≈ 7604 km/s
Added complexity increases error rather than improving fit


Residuals & Redshift Test


Residual scatter increases primarily at highest redshift
Data split into low-z and high-z subsets
Low-z: stable slope, low error
High-z: unstable, noise-dominated





Interpretation


Strong positive distance–velocity relationship observed
Linear model captures dominant physical trend
Deviations at large distances likely due to observational uncertainty





Limitations


Analysis focused on low-redshift supernovae
Measurement uncertainty increases at large distances
More complex cosmological models not explored


Conclusion


Linear model provides an effective description of expansion at low redshift
Nonlinear models do not improve predictive performance
Hubble’s Law remains valid for this dataset

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Residuals & Interpretation

Residuals increase slightly with distance
Pattern suggests growing observational uncertainty at large distances
No strong evidence that a nonlinear model is required

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Main Takeaway

Hubble’s Law provides an excellent first-order description of the data
Linear regression yields a stable estimate of H₀
More complex models do not improve performance for this dataset

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Redshift Split Results

Low-redshift subset

n = 645
Slope ≈ 66.8 km/s/Mpc
RMSE ≈ 534 km/s
Stable and consistent with global linear fit

High-redshift subset

n = 1056
Slope ≈ 23.2 km/s/Mpc
RMSE ≈ 16,137 km/s
Unstable, dominated by measurement uncertainty

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text: Redshift vs Velocity

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Residuals by Redshift

Low-redshift residuals remain tightly clustered
High-redshift residuals show much larger scatter

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Trend / Smoothing Check

Apparent curvature is localized to high redshift
Visual smoothing does not improve predictive performance



Large residuals at high distance are not evidence of nonlinear expansion
Errors increase with redshift due to observational uncertainty
Global linear Hubble model remains appropriate for this dataset

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Motivation & Research Question

Pantheon+ provides high-quality Type Ia supernova distances
Ideal for estimating the Hubble constant at low redshift
What functional form best describes distance–velocity?

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Modeling Approach

Expect linear relationship at low redshift (Hubble’s Law)
Linear regression used as baseline model
Quadratic model tested only as a diagnostic for curvature

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:

Residual scatter increases primarily at highest redshift
Data split into low-z and high-z subsets
Low-z: stable slope, low error
High-z: unstable, noise-dominated

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Motivation & Research Question .{smaller}


Pantheon+ provides high-quality Type Ia supernova distances
Ideal for estimating the Hubble constant at low redshift
What functional form best describes distance–velocity?

title: Estimating the Hubble Constant with Pantheon+ Supernovae
text:
Modeling Approach .{smaller}


Expect linear relationship at low redshift (Hubble’s Law)
Linear regression used as baseline model
Quadratic model tested only as a diagnostic for curvature


Hubble Diagram

Strong linear relationship between distance and velocity
Scatter increases slightly at larger distances




Linear Model Performance

RMSE ≈ 711 km/s
High R² indicates strong explanatory power
Slope provides a stable estimate of H₀



Residuals & Redshift Test


Residuals mostly random at low distance
Scatter increases only at highest redshift
Split-z results:

Low-z: stable slope, low error
High-z: unstable, noise-dominated






Conclusion

Quadratic model performs significantly worse (RMSE ≈ 7600 km/s)
Added complexity increases error rather than improving fit
Linear Hubble model remains appropriate at low redshift
